Line 79: Line 79:
=== Day of Anger ===
=== Day of Anger ===
â  
[[Image:Egyptian protests at Giza Jan 25.jpg|thumb|220px|right|A photograph of demonstrators during the night of 25 January 2011, on Nile Street, Giza, near the [[6th October Bridge]], surrounded by police in riot gear. This group of demonstrators later moved to [[Midan Tahrir|al-Tahrir Square]], in [[Downtown Cairo]], where the main protests were being held.]]
[[Image:Egyptian protests at Giza Jan 25.jpg|thumb|220px|right|A photograph of demonstrators during the night of 25 January 2011, on Nile Street, Giza, near the [[6th October Bridge]], surrounded by police in riot gear. This group of demonstrators later moved to [[Midan Tahrir|al-Tahrir Square]], in [[Downtown Cairo]], where the main protests were being held.]]
â
Protests took place in several cities, including Cairo, [[Alexandria]], [[Suez]] and [[Ismailiya]].<ref name="bbc25jan"/> A policeman was reported to have died in Cairo, while in Suez two protesters died.<ref name="bbc25jan"/> In Cairo, police forces used tear gas and water cannons against the protesters, who in turn threw stones at police, eventually forcing them to retreat.<ref name="bbc25jan">{{cite web | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12272836 | title=Egypt protests: Three killed in 'day of revolt' | accessdate=26 January 2011 | date=25 January 2011 | publisher=BBC News Online}}</ref>
+
On the 25th of Januray 2011, Known as Day of Anger, protests took place in several cities, including Cairo, [[Alexandria]], [[Suez]] and [[Ismailiya]].<ref name="bbc25jan"/> Cairo protesters gathered Tuesday morning in-front of the High Court in downtown Cairo within the framework of the activities of the protests, which marks the official celebrations of "Egypt Police Day" ''(a celebration of the [[Law enforcement in Egypt|Egyptian National Police]])''. The demonstration that was in front of the Supreme Court was larger than usual and was able for the first time to break the security cordon and head to Midan Tahrir.
  +   +
A policeman was reported to have died in Cairo, while in Suez two protesters died.<ref name="bbc25jan"/> In Cairo, police forces used tear gas and water cannons against the protesters, who in turn threw stones at police, eventually forcing them to retreat.<ref name="bbc25jan">{{cite web | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12272836 | title=Egypt protests: Three killed in 'day of revolt' | accessdate=26 January 2011 | date=25 January 2011 | publisher=BBC News Online}}</ref>
==== Scale of protests ====
==== Scale of protests ====
â
Thousands protested in [[Cairo]] on 25 January, with 15,000 alone occupying [[Midan Tahrir|Tahrir Square]];<ref name="Egyptians report poor communication services on Day of Anger">{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/egyptians-report-poor-communication-services-day-anger-1|title=Egyptians report poor communication services on Day of Anger|publisher=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=2011-01-25 |accessdate=2011-01-25}}</ref> 20,000 in various locations across Alexandria,<ref name="Egyptians tests Tunisia's Twitter revolution">{{cite web|author=Jonathan Manthorpe|url=http://www.vancouversun.com/news/Egyptians+tests+Tunisia+Twitter+revolution/4168694/story.html|title=Egyptians tests Tunisia's Twitter revolution|publisher=[[The Vancouver Sun]]|date=2011-01-26 |accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref> 200 demonstrators were in the southern city of [[Aswan]], 2000 in the eastern city of [[Ismailiya]]; and about 3000 in the northern city of [[Mahallah]].<ref name="Thousands protests in Egypt">{{cite web|author=Amir Ahmed|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/01/25/egypt.protests/|title=Thousands protests in Egypt|publisher=CNN|date=2011-01-25 |accessdate=2011-01-25}}</ref>
+
Thousands protested in [[Cairo]] on 25 January, with 15,000 alone occupying [[Midan Tahrir|Tahrir Square]];<ref name="Egyptians report poor communication services on Day of Anger">{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/egyptians-report-poor-communication-services-day-anger-1|title=Egyptians report poor communication services on Day of Anger|publisher=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=2011-01-25 |accessdate=2011-01-25}}</ref> 20,000 in various locations across Alexandria,<ref name="Egyptians tests Tunisia's Twitter revolution">{{cite web|author=Jonathan Manthorpe|url=http://www.vancouversun.com/news/Egyptians+tests+Tunisia+Twitter+revolution/4168694/story.html|title=Egyptians tests Tunisia's Twitter revolution|publisher=[[The Vancouver Sun]]|date=2011-01-26 |accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref> 200 demonstrators were in the southern city of [[Aswan]], 2000 in the eastern city of [[Ismailiya]]; and about 3000 in the northern city of [[Mahallah]].<ref name="Thousands protests in Egypt">{{cite web|author=Amir Ahmed|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/01/25/egypt.protests/|title=Thousands protests in Egypt|publisher=CNN|date=2011-01-25 |accessdate=2011-01-25}}</ref> This was the largest demonstrations ever seen in the protests taking place in Egypt since [[1977]] in what was known as '''The Bread Intifada''' or as [[Anwar El Sadat]] called it '''The Thieves Intifada'''.
